question: Question 1-06/07/2013 The reactor is at 100 kW power in manual mode. Which ONE of the following conditions will require a control rod INSERTION to maintain the same power level?

answers.answer: a. Insertion of a negative reactivity worth experiment.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: DOE Fundamentals Handbook, Module X

answers.answer: b. U235 concentration decrease (Fuel Burnup).
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: DOE Fundamentals Handbook, Module X

answers.answer: c. Primary coolant temperature decreases.
answers.feedback: Correct.

answers.answer: d. Xenon buildup.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: DOE Fundamentals Handbook, Module X

question: Question 2-06/07/2013 During a Subcritical Multiplication '1/M' plot, data is required to be taken. What does the 1/M represent?

answers.answer: a. The inverse of fuel elements presented in the core.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: DOE Fundamentals Handbook, Nuclear Physics and Reactor Theory, Volume X, Module Y, Enabling Objective Z.Z

answers.answer: b. The inverse of the moderator coefficient of reactivity.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: DOE Fundamentals Handbook, Nuclear Physics and Reactor Theory, Volume X, Module Y, Enabling Objective Z.Z

answers.answer: c. The inverse migration length of neutrons of varying energies
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: DOE Fundamentals Handbook, Nuclear Physics and Reactor Theory, Volume X, Module Y, Enabling Objective Z.Z

answers.answer: d. The inverse multiplication of the count rate between generations
answers.feedback: Correct.

question: Question 3-06/07/2013 Which ONE of the following is the reason that Xenon peaks after a shutdown?

answers.answer: a. Iodine decays faster than Xenon decays.
answers.feedback: Correct.

answers.answer: b. Samarium decays faster than Xenon decays.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Reed Training Manual, Chapter 10.4

answers.answer: c. Xenon decays faster than Iodine decays.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Reed Training Manual, Chapter 10.4

answers.answer: d. Xenon decays faster than Promethium.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Reed Training Manual, Chapter 10.4

question: Question 4-06/07/2013 Which ONE of the following will be the resulting stable reactor period when a $0.20 reactivity insertion is made into an exactly critical reactor core? Given =0.0070 and λ=0.1?

answers.answer: a. 25 seconds.
b. 32 seconds.
c. 40 seconds.
answers.feedback: Correct.

answers.answer: d. 80 seconds.

question: Question 5-06/07/2013 Which one of the following is the definition of the FAST FISSION FACTOR?

answers.answer: a. The ratio of the number of neutrons produced by fast fission to the number of neutrons produced by thermal fission..
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: DOE Fundamentals Handbook, Volume 2, Module 3, Neutron Life Cycle, p.

answers.answer: b. The ratio of the number of neutrons produced by thermal fission to the number of neutrons produced by fast fission..
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: DOE Fundamentals Handbook, Volume 2, Module 3, Neutron Life Cycle, p.

answers.answer: c. The ratio of the number of neutrons produced by fast and thermal fission to the number of neutrons produced by thermal fission..
answers.feedback: Correct.

answers.answer: d. The ratio of the number of neutrons produced by fast fission to the number of neutrons produced by fast and thermal fission..
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: DOE Fundamentals Handbook, Volume 2, Module 3, Neutron Life Cycle, p.

question: Question 6-06/07/2013 Which ONE of the following describes the MAJOR contributor to the negative temperature coefficient of reactivity in the WSU TRIGA reactor?

answers.answer: a. Decreasing of fuel density.

answers.answer: b. Zr-H Moderator Effects.

answers.feedback: Incorrect REF: Reed Training Manual.

answers.answer: d. Increasing the resonance absorption in the fuel.

question: Question 7-06/07/2013 Which ONE of the following explains the response of a SUBCRITICAL reactor to equal insertions of positive reactivity as the reactor approaches criticality? Each insertion causes a ...?

answers.answer: a. SMALLER increase in the neutron flux resulting in a LONGER time to stabilize.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: DOE Fundamentals Handbook, Volume 2, Module 4, Subcritical Multiplication.

answers.answer: b. LARGER increase in the neutron flux resulting in a LONGER time to stabilize.
answers.feedback: Correct.

answers.answer: c. SMALLER increase in the neutron flux resulting in a SHORTER time to stabilize.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: DOE Fundamentals Handbook, Volume 2, Module 4, Subcritical Multiplication.

answers.answer: d. LARGER increase in the neutron flux resulting in a SHORTER time to stabilize.

question: Question 8-06/07/2013 Reactor A increases power from 10% to 20% with a period of 25 seconds. Reactor B increases power from 80% to 100% with a period of also 25 seconds. Compared to Reactor A, the time required for the power increase of Reactor B is:

answers.answer: a. Longer than A.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. The power of reactor A increases by a factor of 2, while the power of reactor B increases by a factor of 1.25. Since the periods are the same (rate of change is the same), power increase B takes a shorter time..

answers.answer: b. Shorter than A.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. The power of reactor A increases by a factor of 2, while the power of reactor B increases by a factor of 1.25. Since the periods are the same (rate of change is the same), power increase B takes a shorter time..

answers.answer: c. Twice that of A.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, 1982, Sec 8.4, page 8-9.

answers.answer: d. Exactly the same as A.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. The power of reactor A increases by a factor of 2, while the power of reactor B increases by a factor of 1.25. Since the periods are the same (rate of change is the same), power increase B takes a shorter time..

question: Question 9-06/07/2013 Which one of the following correctly describes the relationship between differential rod worth (DRW) and integral rod worth (IRW)?

answers.answer: a. DRW is the slope of the IRW curve at a given location.
answers.feedback: Correct.

answers.answer: b. DRW is the area under the IRW curve at a given location.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: DOE Fundamentals Handbook, Nuclear Physics and Reactor Theory, Volume X, Module Y, Enabling Objective Z.Z

answers.answer: c. DRW is the square root of the IRW curve at a given location.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: DOE Fundamentals Handbook, Nuclear Physics and Reactor Theory, Volume X, Module Y, Enabling Objective Z.Z

answers.answer: d. There is no relationship between DRW and IRW.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: DOE Fundamentals Handbook, Nuclear Physics and Reactor Theory, Volume X, Module Y, Enabling Objective Z.Z

question: Question 10-06/07/2013 Why is the stable negative period following a scram always the same value,- 80 second, regardless of initial power level? The rate of power change is dependent on the:

answers.answer: a. Constant decay rate of prompt neutrons.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: DOE Fundamentals Handbook, Nuclear Physics and Reactor Theory, Volume X, Module Y, Enabling Objective Z.Z

answers.answer: b. Constant decay rate of prompt gamma emitters.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: DOE Fundamentals Handbook, Nuclear Physics and Reactor Theory, Volume X, Module Y, Enabling Objective Z.Z

answers.answer: c. Mean lifetime of the longest lived delayed precursor.
answers.feedback: Correct.

answers.answer: d. Mean lifetime of the shortest lived delayed neutron precursor.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: DOE Fundamentals Handbook, Nuclear Physics and Reactor Theory, Volume X, Module Y, Enabling Objective Z.Z

question: Question 11-06/07/2013 Reactor is at a power level of 50 watts. The operator IMMEDIATELY inserts an experiment with a reactivity worth of $1.00 into the core. This insertion will cause:            Given: T: reactor period, l*: Prompt neutron lifetime; ρ: reactivity insertion; β: beta fraction

answers.answer: a. A delayed reactor period to be equal to NEGATIVE (-) 80 seconds.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Reference:Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, Sec 4.6, page 4-17

answers.answer: b. A number of prompt neutrons equals to a number of delayed neutrons.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Reference:Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, Sec 4.6, page 4-17

answers.answer: c. The immediate reactor period to be a function of the prompt neutron lifetime (T=l*/ρ).
answers.feedback: Correct

answers.answer: d. A sudden change of power that equals to the initial power multiplied by β(1- ρ)/ (β -ρ).
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Reference:Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, Sec 4.6, page 4-17

question: Question 12-06/07/2013 Reactor power doubles in 30 seconds. Based on the period associated with this transient, how long will it take for reactor power to increase by a factor of 10?

answers.answer: a. 80 seconds.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. DOE Fundamentals Handbook, Nuclear Physics and Reactor Theory. P = P0 et/τ. 1st find τ. τ = time/(ln(2)) = 30/0.693 = 43.3 sec. Time = τ × ln(10) = 43.3 × 2.3 =99.7 sec

answers.answer: b. 100 seconds.
answers.feedback: Correct.

answers.answer: c. 120 seconds.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. DOE Fundamentals Handbook, Nuclear Physics and Reactor Theory. P = P0 et/τ. 1st find τ. τ = time/(ln(2)) = 30/0.693 = 43.3 sec. Time = τ × ln(10) = 43.3 × 2.3 =99.7 sec

answers.answer: d. 140 seconds.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. DOE Fundamentals Handbook, Nuclear Physics and Reactor Theory. P = P0 et/τ. 1st find τ. τ = time/(ln(2)) = 30/0.693 = 43.3 sec. Time = τ × ln(10) = 43.3 × 2.3 =99.7 sec

question: Question 13-06/07/2013 Which ONE of the following is the correct reason for an installed neutron source within the core? A startup without an installed neutron source:

answers.answer: a. Is impossible because there would be no neutrons available to start up the reactor.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: DOE Fundamentals Handbook, Nuclear Physics and Reactor Theory.

answers.answer: b. Would be very slow because it would take a long time to build up neutron population from so low a level.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: DOE Fundamentals Handbook, Nuclear Physics and Reactor Theory.

answers.answer: c. Can be compensated for by adjusting the compensating voltage on the source range detector.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: DOE Fundamentals Handbook, Nuclear Physics and Reactor Theory.

answers.answer: d. Could result in a very short period due to the reactor going critical before neutron population built up high enough to be read on nuclear instrumentation.
answers.feedback: Correct.
